question: Regarding hyperplastic arteriosclerosis, which of the following is correct?

answers.option: It is associated with benign nephrosclerosis
It is associated with renal artery stenosis
It is characteristic of malignant hypertension
It can be seen in diabetic patients
It is characteristic of benign hypertension

question: Which of the following four components are included in the tetralogy of Fallot?

answers.option: Pulmonary stenosis, left ventricular hypertrophy, overriding aorta, and atrial septal defect
Right and left ventricular hypertrophy with ventricular septal defect
Mitral stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, overriding aorta, and ventricular septal defect
Pulmonary stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, overriding aorta, and ventricular septal defect
Pulmonary stenosis, left ventricular hypertrophy, overriding aorta, and ventricular septal defect

question: Which of the following is the most common cause of the tetralogy of Fallot?

A 62-year-old woman has had increasing dyspnea for the past 2 years. She now awakens at night with air hunger and a productive cough of frothy sputum. On examination, she has rails in all lung fields. Echocardiography shows an ejection fraction of 30% with a concentric increase in left ventricular size. The valves appear normal. Which of the following underlying diseases does she have?

A child presents in his early postnatal life with cyanosis and clubbing of fingers. He has been diagnosed with tetralogy of Fallot. Which one of the following abnormalities will be present in this child?

answers.option: Pulmonary artery that overrides the ventricular septal defect

question: Inferior ST-elevation myocardial infarction occurs due to an obstruction in which of the following arteries?

A study of atheroma formation leading to atherosclerotic complications evaluates potential risk factors for prevalence in a population. Three factors are found to play a significant role in the causation of atherosclerosis: smoking, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. Which of the following events is the most important direct biologic consequence of these factors?

answers.option: Alterations of endogenous factors regulating vasomotor tone
Conversion of smooth muscle cells to foam cells

question: Severe (malignant) hypertension is characterized by:
A 78-year-old male died due to a complication of malignant hypertension. Which of the following histological findings may be found on a transverse section from his kidney arterioles?
The hallmark of tetralogy of Fallot on chest X-ray is which of the following?

answers.option: Vertical displacement of the heart's apex

question: A 56-year-old male experienced episodes of severe substernal chest pain every time he performs a task that required moderate exercise. The episodes had become more frequent and severe over the past year but they could be relieved with sublingual nitroglycerin. On examination, he was febrile, his pulse was 78 bpm, and his heart beat was regular, with no murmurs or gallops. Laboratory studies showed that his total serum cholesterol and HDL were raised. Which of the following cardiac lesions was present in this person?

A baby is born to a mother whose rubella IgG was negative. The newborn has sensorineural deafness, microphthalmia, and congenital heart disease. These are all features of congenital rubella syndrome. Which of the following abnormality is also most likely related to congenital rubella syndrome?
What is hyaline arteriosclerosis a characteristic of?
In the majority of cases of acute myocardial infarction, elevated levels of troponin were observed within what time period?
A person with mitral valve stenosis presented to the outpatient department. On auscultation, which of the following diagnostic sounds would be detected?

A 45-year-old male experienced crushing substernal chest pain after arriving at work one morning. Over the next 4 hours, the pain persisted and had begun radiating to his left arm. He becomes short of breath, but waits until the end of his 8-hour shift to go to the hospital. An elevated serum level of which of the following laboratory tests would be most useful for the diagnosis of this patient on admission to the hospital?

Most congenital heart diseases arise due to faulty embryogenesis. The most severe anomalies are incompatible with life. Some congenital heart defects are often compatible with life and result in a live birth. Which of the following congenital heart diseases is most common amongst the latter group?
Which of the following signs in a chest X-Ray is most telling if there is congestive heart failure?

A cyanotic baby is brought to the emergency department by her parents with complaints of rapid breathing and hypoxemia. The congenital defect responsible for this is one that causes the aorta to rise from the right ventricle and the pulmonary trunk to rise from the left ventricle. What is the defect called?
What is the most important diagnostic criteria of systemic hypertension?

answers.option: Left ventricular hypertrophy in absence of other cardiovascular pathology

question: What is the type of necrosis seen in myocardial infarction?
Unstable angina is most often due to which of the following?
Valve regurgitation is due to which of the following reasons?

answers.option: Valves do not open at all

question: After how much time in a myocardial infarction does the myocardium appear pale?
How long does irreversible cell injury develop after cardiac ischemia?
What is the initial microscopic change in systemic hypertensive heart disease?

answers.option: Increase in transverse diameter of myocyte

question: Which of these are the most common causes of death after acute coronary occlusion?

answers.option: Decreased cardiac output, pulmonary edema, and fibrillation

question: What are plump, activated macrophages seen in rheumatic fever also called?
Sudden QRS collapse without prior PR lengthening is seen in which of the following?

answers.option: Second degree Mobitz I heart block

Fish-mouth or buttonhole stenosis is seen in which of the following conditions?

A 67-year-old female presents to the clinic with shortness of breath and chest pain on exertion. She experiences breathlessness on climbing more than 2 floors. Her condition improves when she sits down and takes nitroglycerin. Which of the following can be this condition?

A 67-year-old female presents to the clinic with shortness of breath and chest pain on exertion. She experiences breathlessness on climbing more than 2 floors. Her condition improves when she sits down and takes nitroglycerin. The doctor suspects angina. What is the cause of angina?
What is the second most common cause of sudden cardiac death after myocardial infarction?
Which of the following is the most common cause of aortic calcific stenosis?
Which of the following is a myocardial perfusion test?

answers.option: Imaging at rest and after exercise

When do clinical symptoms of aortic stenosis appear?
Cardiomyopathy that leads to hypertrophy of the ventricular wall is due to changes in which of the following?
What is the most common cause of right-sided heart failure?
Which of the following is a non-modifiable risk factor for coronary heart disease?
Which of the following is not a feature of the tetralogy of Fallot?
Aschoff bodies are characteristically seen in which of the following conditions?
Which of the following is another name for stable angina?
Which of the following does not lead to cor pulmonale?
Which of the following complications can develop after 4-7 days of myocardial infarction as a result of action by macrophages?

answers.option: It is one of the common forms of episodic myocardial ischemia
It is caused by disruption of atherosclerotic plaque
It is caused by coronary artery spasm
Its anginal attacks are related to physical activity
It is usually relieved by rest

question: Which of the following does not lead to aortic regurgitation?
Which of the following is the most common cause of right heart failure?
In reversible ischemia, thallium spect pictures show which of the following?

answers.option: Defect at stress and normal at rest

question: Hypertension can lead to which of the following?
Which of the following is the most common congenital defect of heart?
What is the condition called when the pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle and the aorta arises from the right ventricle?
What are Aschoff bodies in rheumatic fever?
Which lipid is mainly found in the atherosclerotic plaque?

A patient with a history of rheumatic heart disease, now complains of breathlessness and needs workup for valvular heart disease. The suspected diagnosis is mitral valve stenosis. What is the gold standard for the diagnosis of mitral valve stenosis?
What is true regarding mitral valve prolapse?

answers.option: Bulging into ventricle during ventricular systole

question: Which one of the following is a cause of sudden cardiac death?
What is the most common cardiac defect?
Which of the following statements is correct regarding cor pulmonale?

answers.option: It is characterized by left ventricular hypertrophy
Most commonly caused by disorders affecting chest movements
It may be caused by disorders inducing pulmonary arterial vasoconstriction
Shows marked dilation of right ventricle without hypertrophy
It can occur following a massive pulmonary embolism

question: Which of the following conditions is associated with onion skin lesions in the vessels?

answers.option: Increase in concentric smooth muscles of media

question: What causes secondary renal hypertension?

answers.option: Second degree Mobitz I heart block

question: Which of the following is a nonmodifiable risk factor for atherosclerosis?
Which of the following conditions can lead to concentric hypertrophy of the left ventricle?

A 22-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine checkup. She has a short, webbed neck and short stature. Cytogenic analysis shows a karyotype of 45, XO. Which of the following heart defects is most likely to be present in this condition?

A 32-year-old man comes to the clinic with complaints of dyspnea, fatigue, exercise intolerance, and palpitations. On examination, he has a right ventricular heave, a holosystolic murmur, and a fixed, wide split S2. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
Which of the following statements is most appropriate regarding congenital heart defects?

answers.option: Severe pulmonary atresia leads to hypoplastic left ventricle
Pulmonary atresia is associated with left ventricular endocardial fibroelastosis
Severe congenital aortic stenosis leads to hypoplasia of the right ventricle
Aortic stenosis can lead to left ventricular hypertrophy
Tricuspid atresia is associated with hypoplastic left ventricle

Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of sudden cardiac death?
Which of the following clinical conditions is described as having chest pain during exertion which is usually relieved upon rest?
At around what time after myocardial infarction, do the myocardial histopathologic features show fibrovascular granulation tissue around the necrotic area?
Which of the following congenital anomalies of the heart is most commonly detected in adulthood?
Which of the following disorders can be a result of congenital anomalies like trisomies 13, 21 and XO?

The biopsy report from a renal arteriole of a patient with chronic hypertension reveals thickening of the vessel wall, with pink hyaline deposits and luminal narrowing. Which of the following terms best defines this morphology?
Patent ductus arteriosus, a congenital anomaly of the heart is most commonly associated with which of the following risk factors?
Which of the following environmental factors is responsible for the development of rheumatic heart disease?
What is the most appropriate lifestyle modification to prevent coronary artery disease?
Which of the following is the most lethal dysrhythmia?
Which one of the following is the most diagnostic physical sign of congestive cardiac failure?

answers.option: Fine crests at bases of lung

question: Which of the following cardiac anomalies is characterized by the fish-mouth appearance of the valves?
Which of the following is the most common type of angina?
Which of the following statements regarding transmural infarction is correct?

answers.option: Thrombus resulting from plaque disruption is therapeutically lysed
The myocardial necrosis extends across the full thickness of the wall
It results from prolonged reduction in systemic blood pressure
It can occur due to endogenous catecholamines or drugs

question: A 48-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a complaint of chest pain for the past 4-5 hours. He is profusely sweating and also has slight dyspnea. Which of the following is expected to be elevated?

A 56-year-old man was brought to the emergency department by his office colleagues with complaints of severe crushing chest pain associated with dyspnea and sweating for the past hour. He was immediately given a vasodilator but the pain did not subside. If the patient's condition does not improve and prolongs for more than 40 minutes, which of the following conditions can develop?

A 48-year-old man experienced deep localized chest pain associated with dyspnea and sweating which was relieved with rest. According to him, the pain developed after a long tiring day at his job. Pain in this condition is induced due to the release of which of the following mediators?
A 75-year-old male died due to complications of malignant hypertension. A biopsy of the kidney was done. Which of the following histological findings may be found in this case?

A 58-year-old man presents to the outpatient department with a complaint of reduced exercise tolerance over the past five years. In the past year, he has noticed chest pain after climbing stairs. He smokes two packs of cigarettes per day. On examination, he has a blood pressure of 155/95 mmHg. Laboratory investigations include total serum cholesterol of 245 mg/dL, with high-density lipoprotein cholesterol of 22 mg/dL. Which of the following vascular abnormalities is most likely to have developed in this patient?
An atrial septal defect is one of the most common congenital heart diseases. Which of the following structures is involved in this defect?
What is the most common type of lipid present in atheroma plaque?
Which of the following blood vessels is the most prone to atherosclerosis?

answers.option: At the point of bifurcation of arteries

question: A patient comes to the emergency department 4-5 hours after a myocardial infarction. Which of the following cardiac markers will be detected at this point?
A 50-year-old patient presented to the emergency department with a myocardial infarction of the inferior wall of the left ventricle. Which of the following arteries is most likely to be damaged?
One of the presentations in right-sided heart failure patients, who are chronically bedridden, is anasarca. What does the term anasarca mean?
Which of the following findings is associated with Cushing syndrome?
A boy had his blood coalesce on his finger. At the distal area of coalescence, increased blood flow occurred. What is this mechanism called?
Which of the following is not a risk factor for atherosclerosis?
In a newborn, it is found that the aorta arises from the right ventricle and the pulmonary artery from the left ventricle. What is this condition called?
Which cellular component is found in atheromatous plaques?
A woman had a breast lesion which increased the flow of blood to that area. What is this increased blood flow called?

An infant is born with cyanosis. On examination, a heart murmur is auscultated. Echocardiography shows an overriding aorta, ventricular septal defect, right ventricular hypertrophy, and pulmonary stenosis. Which of the following is the most likely congenital disease?

A 60-year-old healthy woman visited the OPD for her health status check-up and the only finding is a mid-systolic click on auscultation of the heart. Within 3 years she has increasing dyspnea. Echocardiography shows mitral regurgitation due to prolapse of a leaflet. Which of the following pathologic changes is most likely present in this valve?

A 45-year-old man has had poorly controlled hypertension ranging from 150/100 mm Hg to 160/110 mm Hg for the past 11 years. Since 3 months his blood pressure has increased to 250/125 mm Hg. The physical examination was unremarkable. The X-ray chest shows a prominent left heart border. Laboratory studies show that his serum creatinine level has increased. Which of the following vascular lesions is most likely to be found in the patient’s kidneys?

A 58-year-old male presented to the ER in the early morning with complains of severe chest pain, radiating to left arm and shortness of breath. He was experiencing mild to moderate chest pain since night. ECG shows findings of myocardial infarction. What morphological changes would you expect on light microscopy after 12 hours of myocardial infarction?

A 48-year-old male, known smoker and diabetic, presents to the hospital with chest pain and dizziness. The physician suspects a coronary pathology. Coronary arteriography shows significant atherosclerotic involvement of left coronary artery. Which of the following morphological change is seen in atherosclerosis?

answers.option: Calcification is seen in early stage
Hyaline deposition is present in the center

question: Which of the following morphological finding is seen in systemic hypertensive heart disease?

answers.option: Decrease in transverse diameter of the myocyte

question: A 70-year-old man with a prolonged history of smoking survived a myocardial infarction 2 years old. He now complains of chest and leg pain during exercise. On examination, blood pressure is 165/100 mmHg. Peripheral pulses are poor in the lower extremities. There is a 6-cm pulsating mass in the midline of the lower abdomen. Which of the following vascular lesions is most likely to be present in this patient?
